newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian scientists want more "Dolly" clones.
newsitem.headline: Australian scientists want more "Dolly" clones.

text.p: Australia's official research body on Friday backed the use of cloning in animal breeding and said it hoped to have cloned livestock on farms in five years.
The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) hailed the technique used in Britain in the first-ever cloning of an adult animal -- a sheep named Dolly.
"It is a great scientific advance and one that we welcome," said Kevin Ward, head of genetic animal research for the CSIRO.
News last Sunday of Dolly's creation ignited debate over the ethics of cloning, prompting U.S. President Bill Clinton to call for an official bioethics report on the development.
One commentator in Britain warned that unscrupulous doctors could go on to produce human "Frankensteins".
But the CSIRO welcomed the new technology and said it could be used to duplicate elite farm animals in Australia within about five years, given the current pace of research.
"Most of the technology is in place, just not the fine detail," Ward told Reuters.
Australian researchers have been looking at cloning for a long time and have made several advances, he said.
Ward described the work of the British research team that produced Dolly as groundbreaking and said it would go a long way to furthering the CSIRO's own research.
Dolly was cloned from the egg cell of one ewe and a mammary gland cell from another.
